author: bsmarthen
title: Nice set
review: This thing is huge! New tracks for this set. The build was easy went together very quickly. Engine compartment opens to show the fan blade and motor. The blade moves up and down . It can be left in the up position. No real new pieces except for the arms of the blade and the tracks. Love the new sets like this - it's going to be a good year to be a Lego fan. Must have set, maybe 2.

author: SRoode
title: Almost Perfect
review:
This is a very detailed set that was very fun to put together.  I love the treads on the dozer, and the attention to detail that Lego is seeming to provide in all of their new City sets.  That being said, there are one or two problems with the set.  When you try to lower the blade, the arms almost always pop off of the blade.  Also, the side cab extensions by the doors are a little loose, and rattle a bit.  Other than that, a very nice model.

Pros:
Big
Detailed
Nice tread movement when rolled on a carpet
Fun to build

Cons:
Poor arm attachment to the blade
Rattling side cab extensions

author: YellowedWhitePieces
title: Not perfect, but close.
review:
This is a great-looking set out of the box, but it needs a bit of reworking to be made a bit sturdier.  Using extra pieces from other sources, I moved the mounting bricks (at the sides of the vehicle) for the dozer blade arms forward by one stud.  Otherwise, the blade supports nearly brush the front of the tracks, behind the blade.

The blade itself is simply too weak as is.  I used two 4X6 plates to stiffen the back of the blade.  This required rebuilding the back of the blade mount quite a bit, but the larger plates do wonders for stiffening the blade.  I also used a pair of 1X10 plates to reinforce the backside of the blade at the top.  As mentioned previously, the lifting cylinders are a bit tight and sometimes come apart.  

Four of the six 1X1 transparent orange plates are put in some very strange places. Two are in the cab, invisible below the sloped brick/control panel piece.  Two more are outside, placed just below the rear of the engine, barely visible.  These four tiny plates are much too interesting and useful to be wasted there.  The two transparent orange 1X1 plates used at the front of the vehicle, below the blade lifting cylinders are actually somewhat okay there, but the entire area where the lift cylinders are mounted is simply too weak.  Some careful thinking and use of some narrow plates and sloped bricks will help to firm up this area.  

The cab should have a rear window.  The fan looks cool, but seems impractical, exposed to "dust" from a construction site.  :)  I also recommend adding some headlights mounted at the top of the engine housing.

As an AFOL/collector, I like to mod my kits to make them stronger and as realistic as the medium allows.  This dozer is an excellent base kit for doing just that!

author: Pulpdiction
title: I really like it
review:
I've seen a fiar bit of criticism of this set but I really like it, the only thing for me that lets it down is that the cab is very weak and I think this was an easy fix by lego so they didn't need to release it like this.  Also I would have liked the cab roof to fold open so you can access the minifig easily, again and easy mod which I have done myself but lego could have done this.

I think is good value in terms of number of parts for your money, especially as this is on sale in Tesaco in the UK right now for Â£15, go grap yourselves a bargain.

author: Rad
title: Nice set out of the box.
review:
This set was fun to build, I love the proportions compared to the minifig. The tracks are cool and they move like the real thing.

My only gripes are the front vent, it doesn't really go all the way down and there is a gap at the bottom. A similar thing with the doors for the driver compartment.

Another thing is the upper arms for the blade are pretty flimsy and sometimes get stuck. The front window and sides of the driver compartment are also a bit flimsy.

Other than that, this is a nifty set.

author: jjr
title: really cool
review:
I first didn't want to buy city sets anymore and focus more on starwars. however it's yellow color and industrial apperance made me want this set. and to make things even better it was 10 euro's cheaper (bhought it at toys XL a.k toysrus) so lets start

minifigs: you get one standard construcion worker, 

build: build is easy because of the separated bags. seometimes I made some small mistakes (I never did that before) but I saw them and could solve the problems. I dont know this has to do with the instruction or me...

play: the final product is a really oversized (in minifig scale) dozer. the enormous tracks are awsome and the front digger is cool. it has a lot of functions and it is fun to drive it around,

value to money: the set had a discount of 10 euro's wich made it 25 euro instead of 35. 25 is a very good price for this set. but 35 looks for me a little overpriced, but still the dozer is really worth it.

author: mattressnz
title: Almost a great set.
review:
The build was great, although with this set, and other recent sets, it seems Lego have tried to 'dumb down' the instructions. There are over 100 steps in the book, a lot  of which reqiure the addition of only one part. Also, the numbered bags seem a bit unnecessary, there are only 352 pieces. My 7 year-old opened all the bags, dumped the pieces in a pile on the table then built the dozer using every 3rd or 4th step.

    As other reviews have mentioned, the cab and blade require strengthening, which is easily done. A big let-down for me was the absence of rippers on the back, a must for a dozer this size I reckon! However there is plenty of room at the back and it took me about 20 minutes to correct this oversight and add a winch as well.

    Those gripes aside, I would still highly recommend this set, and it looks great on the back of my transporter 5590.

author: Zapp_Brannigan
title: Hugely HUGE!
review: Forget simply clearing away dirt, this monster is big enough to demolish BUILDINGS! The blade is larger than some buildings and vehicles in my city! Imagine what would happen if this dozer fell into the wrong hands. Anyways, to start small, the set comes with a minifigure and a fence with red stripes and lights. When you put the fence stickers on, you gotta be careful the force applied to put the sticker on doesn't bend the fence, because it can bend too easily. Overall, the dozer is about 20 studs wide and 14 studs high, like I said, huge. It cannot make 90 degree turns on conventional road plates. The blade, specifically, is 20 studs wide and about 10 studs high, enough to level ANYTHING that gets in its way. The blade can move up and down, a system of "hydraulic pumps" allows this. However, the grey axels (circular) slip out of the cylinders way too easily, but this can be fixed by replacing them with Technic axels (the ones shaped like a cross). Also, sometimes the blade is uneven when it raises/lowers. To solve this, you have to use your thumb to hold on to the 1x6 grey plate right above the fan) and use the rest of your fingers to slowly and carefully lift or push down the special yellow beams attached to the sides of the blade and vehicle. This way, the blade won't fall off, and it will be easier to raise/lower the blade. It's been a long time since I saw doors on vehicles, so this is another good thing. The caterpillar tracks work very well; they work on almost any surface and make a realistic grinding sound. There are a total of 58 track pieces, 29 for each caterpillar track. There is a fan on the front, covered by a ventilated flap. The cab has a COMPUTER inside with levers. Overall great set great price, and again, it's huge! You will be impressed if you get this set.

author: HQuiff
title: The Most Monstrous Machine In LEGO City - Or LEGO Town
review:
Intro-
Combined with a sharp spiky engine cooler, and a huge front bucket, this thing is unstoppable. It's heavy duty treads (28 single clip-on tracks on each side) make it run practically everywhere. This... is the thing most likely to catch my eye on a LEGO City Construction display!

I received this just yesterday (The 24th of August 09') as a present from my Aunt. And seriously... this thing just towers over every other vehicle on the street, or on the roads! That said, it doesn't work very well on the flat roads you can get for your town. It works better on uneven surfaces like beds and carpets, however it still is able to run across flat surfaces (Preferably not roads).

The actual build took around 20 - 30 Minutes, mainly because I spilt my half cup of tea everywhere with a shifty move from my elbow. In any case, the build was fun, especially building the base and the engine. Except when coming closer to the end, I ran into some problems; some of the linking Technic parts wouldn't fit in! It wasn't a fault of the instructions, it was a mistake I had made of accidentally putting some pieces facing the wrong way. So my advice... just follow the instructions carefully.

The thing I will say about this set... is the remarkable amount of working functions, such as the opening doors near the cockpit, the door for the engine cooler being able to open so smoothly, the nice and crafty way the front bucket can slip up and down, and also the way you can lower the bottom bit of the bucket downwards completely. And finally, the easy way the roof on the cockpit can open so you can slip for Minifig in without having to fumble him around so that he can sit down!

Well, that's about all I think of. And if you have any unanswered questions, I highly advise you to actually get the set, as I recommend it any LEGO City collector or fan. Overall an 8.1/10, or 4/5.

author: parchioso
title: A minifigs compatible Dozer (when compared to the complex 8275 Bulldozer)
review:
When you have a lot of debris on a construction site, you need a bulldozer to handle them, 7685 Dozer is a simplified 8275 Bulldozer, but still has a lot of details with a moderate size, good value for the price.

I have bought 8275 Motorized Bulldozer for almost an year, but as a complex Technic set, I can't find time to build it. This medium size dozer is easy to build (still has 9" X 5"), and quite good looking really, though the playability is only average.

It has 58 pieces of Technic Chain Tread while 8275 Bulldozer has 84, at a low price it is a good source for getting these parts for other MOCs.

As others had pointed out, the arms and front portion are not very stable. But overall it is good looking and easy to build, and the pricing is fair, compared to 8275, this one is minifigs-compatible and does not take up too much space, so it is really worth buying.

I have some pictures posted at Flickr: 
http://www.flickr.com/photos/parchioso/sets/72157615802853205

author: Boidoh
title: CHRISTMAS GIFT
review:
I got this for Christmas with a incomplete Front-End Loader and a tow-truck which was complete. This set it really nice.

Pros-
1. threads, hard to find in sets.
2. The little hook thing at the front, i used my tow truck to tow it when it runs out of gas.
3. lights
4. cooling fan, hidden

Cons-
1. Cab and the front area breaks off easy.
2. When i put on the blade it wont make the threads move so i removed it. never putting it back on.
3. Runs not at all on smooth surfaces. Thats were my tow truck tows it..

BUY IT.

author: Chilli96
title: Big, Big, Big!
review:
This set is very big and comes with a little barrier with lights on top!

Pros
 - Little barrier
 - Treads move
 - Little doors open
 - Fan inside
 - Big Bulldozer Blade
 - Chimney!
 - Opening Door thing on front.

Cons
 - Treads won't move on smooth surfaces

author: Legocityfanatic
title: Great set, I had a problem while building, though.
review:
This is an exceptional set, when I saw it at the store, I knew it was mine! When I finished building I realized there was a problem with the blade lifting function, it was either breaking of or barely moving. 

                                                        Instructions

The instructions were relatively easy to follow, not much more to say.

                                                              Parts

I liked how some of the parts in this set were Technic pieces. They snapped together easily and worked well together.

                                                          Minifigures

Well, one minifigure is *cough* lame for an enormous set like this one. The fig isn't too rare either.

                                                            The build

was very good. I liked the fan under the grill, those things that looked like fans on the sides were good details. There were other details like the control system inside, the smokestack, and the warning barrier on the outside, which looks tiny compared to the gigantic dozer.

                                                     The completed model

is huge! It looks good in a construction site in your city, or even better when on display! As I said there is a problem for me with the blade functions, but that's the only flaw.

                                                              Summary
In all, this is a great set to have, if you see it for sale for a modest price, go ahead and buy it!

author: av8r1973
title: Monster behemoth of a dozer - sweet-looking vehicle
review:
Big.  No, huge.  No, enormous!  The blade on this behemoth is 20 2/3 studs wide (with the side cutters)!  It is "minifig scale" only because it comes with a minifig.  I am not quite sure how the little dude actually gets up to the cab.  Helicopter?  Jet pack?  The beast is truly out of place within the city, even amongst the other sets.  The large Heavy Hauler with the bridge unit is dwarfed by it.  Getting the point?

There are a couple of cons that stand out that really do detract from the set.  It's too bad, because they aren't difficult to resolve.  The cab falls apart just by touching it.  The base of the windshield is the only part for any studs to grip.  Unfortunately, this makes a natural place to try to drive the dozer from.  Instant catastrophe.  Second, the hydraulic cylinders for the blade look great and do a good job holding the blade up, but the piston comes out of either the barrel or out of the blade-end each time the blade is lowered.  It makes it rather unusable.

Lastly, for another $5-10 USD, a nice set of ripper teeth should have been included.  This is about the size of a D9 Cat and anything this size has them.  Even the 8275 has them.

Despite the size, and the cons listed, this thing is cool!  It is about 1/2 the size of the Technic 8275, but has the same treads (29 per side).  Nice Technic cogs and some nice Technic elements to make the build more sturdy.  It looks great on the construction site!  I need to find a large pile of brown and tan studs and small bricks now...  The engine construction was cool!  I am sure some of the parts are normal in the Racers or Bionicle sets, but they are new for me.  The air cleaners and fan were cool to me.  I actually like that better than the "working V-8" model installed in some of my Technic sets.  Too bad you can't see all the detail once the cowling is installed.

The build was fun.  My 3yo built the first two bags and my 5yo built the 3rd bag.  Short attention spans kicked in.  They were both happy to see stickers.  I was happy to see several new elements I didn't have before.  LEGO really did a nice selection of elements for this dozer.  They really make the beast more realistic.

If you have a dedicated construction site - get this dozer.  It's just cool.  If you want a standalone set to look at and drive across the living room, this is still a pretty good kit (though I would remove the cab if this is the case).  If you want to add to your city, find a different set.  This is just too big for that.

author: ViceMan
title: Behemoth of the construction site.
review:
I think this set is a little out of place with the other construction sets due to its sheer scale, only the 7344 dump truck set (which I don't have) tops it. It would be more appealing if it were slightly smaller and of comparable size to the other construction sets, and in turn those sets were scaled up slightly.

Aside from the scale issues it's a good set with a very technic-oriented design, which isn't a bad thing. There are a few pleasing additions that flesh out the vehicle and give the impression that Lego actually put some thought into the model.

Overall I have mixed feelings about this set. But the pros outweigh the cons.

author: redbeardlegoman
title: Big Beautiful Bulldozer!  Bundles of Brawn,  But Brings Binary Boo-hoos.
review:
Look at this lovely yellow mountain of earth-scraping delight!  We know who's the boss around here, don't we?  Too bad the big fella comes with two Achilles' heels. 

Pros

  • Pro 1 It's just so big!  I mean, there aren't a lot of parts, but they are maxed out to make this BBW as sweet as pie.  The other equipment in the yard trembles in intimidation and not a little awe.
  • Pro 2 Great detailing.  I absolutely love everything about the engine.
  • Pro 3 A fantastic amount of tread pieces in one set.

Cons

  • Con 1 The blade's "hydraulic" arms always pop out whenever you use it.  That is, if you can move the blade at all without...
  • Con 2 ... popping the cab off!  Grrrr!  These two issues, almost (but not quite), kill this dozer for me.
  • Con 3 For the size and the price, there could have been either a little more added to it, like a winch, rippers, or teeth on the blade.  Or, as with the Single-drum Roller (7746), there could have been another minifig doing something.

Though there are two (quite annoying) faults with this yard monster, I still recommend it.  It simply looks awesome on-site, and really ups the wow factor of any city.
